title: IPv6 Addressing
description: Understanding IPv6 address structure, types, compression, and configuration

keyConcepts.title: IPv6 Address Format
keyConcepts.description: 128-bit addresses written as eight 16-bit hexadecimal hextets separated by colons (e.g., 2001:0DB8:0000:0001:0000:0000:0000:0001). Much larger address space than IPv4.

keyConcepts.title: IPv6 Compression Rules
keyConcepts.description: Leading zeros in each hextet can be omitted. The longest contiguous sequence of all-zero hextets can be replaced with '::' (but only once per address). Example: 2001:0DB8:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0001 becomes 2001:DB8::1

keyConcepts.title: Global Unicast Address Structure
keyConcepts.description: Three parts: (1) Global Routing Prefix (assigned by ISP), (2) Subnet ID (internal organization), (3) Interface ID (identifies specific host). Standard is /64 prefix.

keyConcepts.title: Link-Local Addresses
keyConcepts.description: Automatically assigned to every IPv6 interface. Prefix FE80::/10. Non-routable, used only for local subnet communication. Required for IPv6 operation and Neighbor Discovery Protocol.

keyConcepts.title: IPv6 Address Types
keyConcepts.description: Unicast (one-to-one), Multicast (one-to-many), Anycast (one-to-nearest). No broadcast in IPv6 - replaced by multicast.

keyConcepts.title: Loopback Address
keyConcepts.description: ::1 is the IPv6 loopback address (equivalent to 127.0.0.1 in IPv4). Used to test that IPv6 is properly installed on the local host.

importantPoints: Written as 8 hextets of 16 bits each, separated by colons
Leading zeros in hextets can be dropped: 0DB8 â†’ DB8
One contiguous group of all-zero hextets can become '::' (only once)
Standard IPv6 prefix length is /64 (64-bit network, 64-bit interface ID)
Global unicast addresses: 2000::/3 (routable on the internet)
Unique local addresses: FC00::/7 (private, like RFC 1918 in IPv4)
Unspecified address: :: (all zeros, used before address is assigned)
IPv6 does NOT use broadcast - uses multicast instead
Minimum requirement for IPv6 interface: link-local address
/48 to /64 provides 16 bits for subnetting (65,536 subnets)
Interface ID is last 64 bits in a /64 address
First 64 bits (4 hextets) are the network prefix in /64
